Award.AwardTitle: Gordon Research Conference on Photonuclear Reactions and Frontiers and Careers in Photonuclear Physics in Holderness, NH, August 10-15, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support of the 2014 Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Photonuclear Reactions, which will be held at the Holderness School in Holderness, NH from August 10 - 15, 2014. The Gordon Conference serves as a forum for the presentation of the newest ideas and results in the field, and plays an important role in driving forward theoretical and experimental work on electromagnetic reactions in nuclear physics. Ronald Gilman of Rutgers University, the PI of this proposal, is chair of the meeting. The money will be used to support domestic travel costs and registration fees of junior scientists. The award will also support an associated conference "Frontiers and Careers in Photonuclear Reactions," during the two days immediately prior to the GRC. This Frontiers meeting is organized by and for junior scientists and is meant to provide an introduction to the topics that will be discussed at the GRC.

The broader significance of this award is in the training of junior scientists. The participation of junior scientists is a focus of the Gordon Research Conferences organization, with the intent of having the junior scientists interact extensively and develop a network of scientific collaborators, while also developing the breadth and depth of their physics knowledge, leading to greater career achievements. The Gordon Photonuclear Reactions Conferences have been notable for the large attendance of junior scientists. For the 2012 Conference, 30% of attendees were graduate students, and 14% were postdocs. It is very noteworthy that 27% of attendees were women, far in excess of the percentage of women in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Gordon Research Conferences are designed to promote ideas at the frontiers of science through private, not-for-attribution conferences. While the conference programs are published, no recordings are allowed and there are no proceedings. This format encourages to presentation of preliminary results and speculative ideas. The Conference format, in particular the scheduling of sessions, the somewhat remote location, and the combination of a reception with a poster session, also encourages interactions between the attendees.

The 2014 Gordon Conference on Photonuclear Physics was a success in part due to National Science Foundation support, which provided travel support to help 24 graduate students and postdocs attend the conference. Attendance increased from 108 at the 2012 Conference to 119. Of particular note is that about 1/3 of the speakers and discussion leaders, and 28% of attendees, were women, far in excess of the percentage of women physics faculty (about 14%) and even of women physics graduate students (about 20%).

The 2014 Photonuclear Conferees were also about one-third from Europe, which broadens the topical coverage due to differences between the US and European research programs.

Graduate students and postdocs made up about 43% and 16% of the conferees, respectively. The experience of the graduate students and postdocs was enhanced by a related but independent meeting organized by and for them, Frontiers and Careers in Photonuclear Physics, held at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology immediately preceding the Photonuclear Conference. About half of the Gordon students and postdocs attended Frontiers. At Frontiers, they had the opportunity to give oral presentations in a friendly environment in front of a smaller audience. Sessions were also held on aspects of job hunting.
